node.title: Common Sense Advice On Handling Most Joint Injuries On Your Own ‚Äì [Part 2 of 2]
node.summary:
In Part 1 of handling most joint injuries on your own I emphasized the importance of self-administering first aid within the first 48 hours.
Taking care of an injury immediately after it occurs the right way, in large part determines how long you‚Äôll be able to travel with ease again.
At the first sign of pain stop your stretch and carefully move your joint back to rest.

Take care of yourself and your body will take care of you for many more travels to come!

node.title: Airline Feeding Frenzy
node.summary:
The onslaught of √† la carte fees by the airlines is another in a growing number of reasons of why the airline industry needs to be run like a public utility.
As a result we have a $439USD advertised flight that, with added fees, ends up being almost $700.
You not only get the thrill of long line-ups and flight delays you have the opportunity of paying for the privilege.
For example, on American Airlines, passengers flying within the U.S. pay $20 USD for their first checked bag and $30 for the next one.
Now the passengers pay for services the airlines already have to buy.

node.title: Use Your Next Trip To Solve That Big Problem You Have Back Home
node.summary:
Traveling doesn‚Äôt make your problems go away, it just brings them along for the ride.
Although your next trip likely won‚Äôt solve dilemmas directly, vagabonding can redirect your focus in unique ways, preparing you to tackle life crises of all sizes.
That‚Äôs part of the reason everyone seems so ‚Äúnew‚Äù to us upon returning home after a long trip.
Chemicals like cortisol and adrenaline sharpen your senses, giving you faster reaction times to tiger attacks and the occasional life-challenge.
So, even if your problems are waiting for your after your next trip, your journey may have just given you enough neural ammunition to tackle them effectively.
